courseDescription: This course will introduce students to the needs, access, evaluation, use, impact and ethical/legal aspects of information, as well as to the application of information literacy and research in the fields of civil and environmental engineering.

courseTitle: Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics in civil and/or environmental engineering at the introductory level.
Introduction to engineering problems and their solutions through a study of the statics of particles and rigid bodies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Static analysis of particles and rigid bodies

courseDescription: This course is designed to assist engineering students in acquiring a more thorough knowledge and proficiency in engineering mechanics. The course follows CEE 204 in the mechanics sequence. In this course, kinematics of particles and rigid bodies, mass moments of inertia, acceleration, work, energy, power, and special applications in the civil engineering field, such as inertia problems in vehicle collisions, rudiments of wave dynamics, etc. are included.
Technical and Digital Skills: Kinematics of particles and rigid bodies
Special applications in civil engineering like inertia problems in vehicle collisions and wave dynamics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of complex engineering problems
Application of theoretical concepts to real-world scenarios
Problem-solving in special applications like vehicle collisions and wave dynamics

courseDescription: This course provides fundamental theories to understand the strength of materials focused on civil engineering applications. It will cover stress-strain relationship, equilibrium of deformable bodies and behavior of axially loaded members. It will also analyze for stresses, strains, and deformation of members subjected to torsions in both elastic and inelastic ranges. Other topics, such as buckling and stability of columns, Mohr circle, and energy methods will also be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of stresses and strains in axially loaded members
Deformation analysis of members under torsion
Buckling and stability analysis of columns
Mohr circle analysis for material properties
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for stress and strain calculations
Analyzing deformation under different loading conditions

courseTitle: Geographic Information Systems in Civil and Environmental Engineering
courseDescription: Geographic Information Systems as they apply to civil and environmental engineering. Spatial data acquisition, generation and analysis methods from terrestrial, aerial and satellite sources. Modeling of terrain, land, and hydrographic information using CAD and GIS software in the creation and application of CAD design and GIS spatial databases to engineering problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing terrestrial, aerial, and satellite data sources
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective data visualization for engineering problems
Collaborating on CAD and GIS projects
Presenting spatial data analysis findings to a non-technical audience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing spatial data for engineering solutions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing CAD and GIS projects effectively
Leading teams in the creation of spatial databases for engineering projects

courseTitle: Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
courseDescription: Topics in civil and/or environmental engineering at the basic engineering level.

courseTitle: Probability and Statistics for Civil Infrastructure
courseDescription: This course studies the fundamentals of probability and statistics that are widely used in various fields of engineering. Specific areas of study include probability theory, counting methods, statistics and parameters, propagation of error, probability distribution functions, central limit theorem, hypothesis testing, linear regression, and correlation analysis. Applications of statistics and probability analysis in civil and environmental engineering will be discussed through examples. Furthermore, an introduction to data science and an overview of applications of artificial intelligence in CEE problems will also be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Artificial intelligence applications in CEE problems

courseTitle: Numerical Methods for Civil and Environmental Engineering
courseDescription: Introduction to selected numerical methods and their applications in solving civil and environmental engineering problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data visualization tools for engineering data
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Optimization techniques for civil and environmental engineering challenges
Critical thinking in numerical solution strategies

courseDescription: Analysis of statically determinate structures.  Influence lines and structural design.  Displacement calculations.  Introduction to analysis of indeterminate structures.
Properties of steel, portland cement concrete, bituminous concrete, aggregates, and timber.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of portland cement concrete composition

courseDescription: Fundamental engineering properties of soil and their application to earth structures and foundations.  Topics include seepage, compaction, strength, and deformation characteristics of soils.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of soil mechanics to earth structures and foundations
Understanding soil strength and deformation characteristics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing soil properties for engineering applications
Identifying and addressing seepage issues in soil structures
Analyzing soil strength data for structural design
Deformation analysis of soil under different conditions

courseDescription: Performance of various soil mechanics tests, including gradation, index testing, compaction, density, permeability, consolidation, shear tests for soils are conducted for students to gain hand-on experiences.  The relevant principles are covered in CEE 323.
Technical and Digital Skills: Performing soil mechanics tests (gradation, index testing, compaction, density, permeability, consolidation, shear tests)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with lab partners on experiments
Presenting findings and analysis to peers
Communicating effectively with lab instructors and assistants
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and resolving issues during testing procedures
Analyzing complex test data to draw conclusions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and coordinating lab experiments efficiently
Assuming leadership roles within lab groups when necessary
Maintaining a clean and organized work environment in the laboratory

courseDescription: Fluid properties, fluid statics and fundamentals of fluid kinematics.  Steady, incompressible conservation laws for mass, momentum and energy including real fluid energy losses.  Turbulent, incompressible fluid flows in closed conduits and with a free surface.  Introduction to thermodynamics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing conservation laws for mass, momentum, and energy

courseDescription: Analysis of closed-conduit flow and open-channel flow.  Principles of surface water hydrology and groundwater hydraulics.  Economics and probability concepts in water resources planning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Probability concepts in water resources planning
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills in surface water hydrology

courseTitle: CE Hydraulics and Water Resources Laboratory
courseDescription: Performing various labs and experiments for hydraulics, hydrology, and water resources for students to gain hand-on experiences. The relevant principles are covered in CEE 340.
Technical and Digital Skills: Hands-on experience with water resources principles

courseDescription: Introduction to the fundamental principles of environmental engineering.  Topics in water quality, water and wastewater treatment, air quality, and solid waste and landfills are discussed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration on environmental projects with team members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data analysis for pollution control strategies

courseDescription: May be repeated for credit.  Available for pass/fail grading only.  Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Development Services prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.

May be repeated for credit.  Available for pass/fail grading only.  Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students to gain short duration career-related experience.
Technical and Digital Skills: Career-related experience in a specific field
Technical skills relevant to the internship role
Utilizing software for data analysis or project management
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional communication with colleagues and supervisors

courseDescription: May be repeated for credit.  Available for pass/fail grading only.  Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students to gain short duration career-related experience.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Short duration career-related experience planning, time management, task prioritization

courseDescription: This course surveys the current practice of transportation engineering in the United States. It focuses on various ground transportation modes and covers policy, institutional planning and operational issues. Students are introduced to planning models, capacity analysis, and traffic impact analysis.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of transportation policies and practices

courseTitle: Topics in Civil and/or Environmental Engineering
courseDescription: Topics in civil and/or environmental engineering.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team collaboration on engineering projects
Client communication and presentation of engineering solutions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation for civil engineering projects
Risk assessment and mitigation strategies in environmental engineering
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in civil and environmental engineering contexts
Team coordination for large-scale engineering projects

courseDescription: The course will cover the practice and business aspects of engineering including concepts in management, business, public policy, and leadership.  It will also cover public and private procurement of work, project management and execution, responsibility to clients, contracting, project finances, professional liability, and public safety.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of public and private procurement processes
Knowledge of project finances and budgeting
Familiarity with professional liability regulations in engineering
Understanding of public safety standards in engineering
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members in project execution
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Risk assessment and mitigation strategies in engineering projects

courseTitle: Civil Engineering Design Project and Professional Practice
courseDescription: For graduating seniors only.  Group design project of civil engineering systems requiring synthesis, data gathering, preliminary investigation, master planning, conceptual designs, layouts, support studies, cost estimates and report writing.  Emphasis will be on alternatives, constraints, economics, ethics and professional practice, business and project management, public policy and leadership. This is a writing intensive course.
Fundamental concepts of reinforced concrete analysis and design by ultimate strength and working stress methods.

Analysis of 2-D and 3-D determinate and indeterminate truss/beam/frame structures by the unified direct stiffness matrix method, for both hand-calculation and computer implementation. Popular commercialized (NASTRAN) software will also be discussed.
Masonry materials, reinforced beams and lintels, walls, columns and pilasters, shear walls, and buildings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Structural analysis of walls, columns, and pilasters
Application of masonry in building design

courseDescription: Load and resistance factor design methods for steel structures.
Technical and Digital Skills: Load and resistance factor design methods

courseDescription: Design of wood structures based on national design specification and load and resistance factor design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Load and resistance factor design implementation

courseDescription: Subsurface exploration, site preparation, design of shallow and deep foundations, and retaining structures.

courseTitle: Slope Stability and Earth Structures Design
courseDescription: Slope stability analysis, including limit equilibrium procedures, finite element method, seepage analysis, and advanced topics such as rapid drawdown, construction of embankments on soft soil, and seismic slope stability. Lateral earth retention systems, including gravity walls, excavation support systems, and applications of geosynthetic material, will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Construction of embankments on soft soil
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in slope stability analysis
Analytical skills in lateral earth retention systems design

courseDescription: An overview of earthquake processes and details of the characteristics of destructive ground motion; the effects of such motion on civil engineering structures; reviews of current design practice in mitigating earthquake hazards for various civil engineering structures such as buildings, bridges, dams, lifelines, ports and harbors, etc.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of destructive ground motion characteristics
Current design practices for earthquake hazard mitigation in civil engineering structures
Structural engineering principles for buildings, bridges, dams, etc.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear communication of seismic risk assessments to stakeholders
Presentation of earthquake engineering solutions to non-technical audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of structural vulnerabilities to seismic activity
Risk assessment and management for civil engineering projects in earthquake-prone regions
Application of seismic design codes and standards to real-world scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for earthquake engineering initiatives
Leading seismic retrofitting projects for existing structures
Coordinating interdisciplinary teams for earthquake resilience planning

courseDescription: This course studies soil and aggregate's physical, chemical and biological stabilization procedures. Students are introduced to chemical stabilization analysis and design using materials such as cement, lime, and fly ash. Physical ground modification, compaction methods and mechanical stabilization application and design are also studied.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design using cement, lime, and fly ash
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of soil and aggregate properties

courseDescription: Hydraulic transients; flow control structures; computer analysis of hydraulic systems; design of pipelines, open channels and culverts.
Storm rainfall analysis, design rainfall hyetographs, runoff calculation procedures, detention basins, use of mathematical models to analyze and design urban storm drainage systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Mathematical modeling for urban storm drainage systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying mathematical models to solve drainage system challenges

courseDescription: Description of well hydraulics in single and multiple well systems.  Determination of aquifer parameters from pumping tests.  Use of computer models to determine drawdowns due to multiple well systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Aquifer parameter determination from pumping tests
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in aquifer parameter estimation
Analytical skills in interpreting pumping test results

courseTitle: Water Distribution and Wastewater Collection System Design
courseDescription: Design of water distribution systems, sanitary sewer systems and appurtenances.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of appurtenances in water systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data for optimal system performance

courseDescription: Discussion of water quality constituents and introduction to the design and operation of water and wastewater treatment facilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing water and wastewater treatment facilities

courseDescription: Study of air quality management standards and regulations and pollutant dynamics.  Design and operation of emission control equipment for mobile and stationary sources of air pollution.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of air quality management standards and regulations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of air quality data and insights
Collaboration with team members on air pollution control projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Implementing solutions to reduce air pollution
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for air quality improvement initiatives
Leading a team in implementing emission control measures

courseDescription: Study of sources, generation rates and characteristics of hazardous wastes and their regulation, handling, and design of treatment and disposal facilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of hazardous waste sources and generation rates
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for waste treatment facilities

courseDescription: Application of engineering methods for the prevention of pollution. Review of the pollution prevention related regulations. Study of source reduction methods, analysis for environmentally conscious manufacturing methods, process changes, life cycle analysis, and water/energy conservation methods. Evaluation of pollution prevention case studies.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management of pollution prevention initiatives

courseDescription: Investigation of complex relationships between humans and coastlines and study of how humans adapt and develop adaptation measures and solutions to tackle flooding caused by rising sea levels and subsequent heavy storm events.  This course also evaluates natural and nature-based systems, engineered systems, different flood-proofing methods, and impacts of sea level rise on coastal water quality and the potential impacts on disease transmission.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluation of natural and nature-based systems
Understanding of engineered systems for flood control
Assessment of impacts on coastal water quality
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with diverse stakeholders in adaptation planning
Effective communication of adaptation measures to communities
Negotiation skills for consensus-building in decision-making processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Risk assessment for potential impacts of sea level rise
Identification of disease transmission risks related to flooding
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for implementing adaptation measures
Leading interdisciplinary teams in adaptation projects
Strategic planning for long-term resilience to sea level rise

courseDescription: Overview of social, economical, technical environmental aspects of regional, national and international efforts to achieve sustainable development.  Discussion of the integration of industrial activity and ecological concerns utilizing principles of zero emissions, pollution prevention and design for the environment.   (WEB Based, On-Line Course)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of sustainable development efforts
Analyzing regional, national, and international sustainable development strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Online project management for sustainable development initiatives
Leadership in integrating industrial activity and ecological concerns

courseDescription: This is the first course in transportation operations and traffic flow theory.  Topics include traffic engineering studies, capacity analysis, intersection control, traffic flow models, shockwave analysis, signal warrant analysis, and safety analysis.  Course includes applications of modeling and simulation to isolated intersections.

This course presents the basic techniques for transportation data analytics. It will discuss statistical modeling, prominent algorithms, and visualization approaches to analyze both small- and large-scale data sets generated from transportation systems. Practices of using different data for various real-world traffic/transportation applications and decision making will also be discussed., STAT 330); any programming language such as C, Python or Java is beneficial but not required.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying patterns in large-scale data sets
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for transportation data analytics

courseDescription: This course provides students with an understanding of basic principles and techniques in order to develop skills in the highway geometric design process. It introduces design methods for three-dimensional layout for roadways, considering cross section (lanes and shoulders, curbs, medians, roadside slopes and ditches, sidewalks), horizontal alignment (tangents and curves), and vertical alignment (grades and vertical curves).
Technical and Digital Skills: Cross section design (lanes, shoulders, curbs, medians, slopes, ditches, sidewalks)

courseDescription: Classical small amplitude wave theory, wave transformations in shallow water, shoaling, refraction, diffraction, reflection, breaking.  Wave induced near shore currents and sediment transport processes.  Alternatives to mitigate coastal erosion processes. Introduction to coastal structures.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of coastal engineering concepts
Collaboration on coastal erosion mitigation projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of wave-induced near shore currents
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for coastal engineering projects
Team coordination for coastal structure implementation

courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in civil and/or environmental engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Recent developments in civil and environmental engineering

courseDescription: Individual analytical, experimental and/or design study selected by the student and supervised by the advisor.

courseDescription: Course covers the overview of renewable energy sources; fundamentals of biofuels; biomass and types of biomass (e.g., woody biomass, forest residues, agricultural residues, energy crops); composition of lignocelluloses (cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin); biomass conversion technologies; thermochemical, supercritical water, and biochemical conversion processes; types of biofuels from biomass; liquid fuels (bioethanol, bio-oil, biocrude, and hydrocarbons); gaseous fuels (synthesis gas, hydrogen, biodiesel); solid fuels (biochar, torrefied biomass); biodiesel from vegetable oils, algae to biofuels; value-added processing of biofuel residues; economic and environmental assessments; policies and future R&D.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with biomass types (woody, forest residues, agricultural residues, energy crops)
Understanding of lignocelluloses composition (cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin)
Knowledge of biomass conversion technologies (thermochemical, supercritical water, biochemical)
Knowledge of biofuels types (liquid fuels, gaseous fuels, solid fuels)
Understanding of biodiesel production from vegetable oils, algae
Knowledge of value-added processing of biofuel residues
Ability to conduct economic and environmental assessments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of policies and future R&D implications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and evaluate biomass conversion processes
Critical assessment of economic and environmental impacts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to guide future R&D efforts in biofuels

Topics include traffic engineering studies, capacity analysis, intersection control, traffic flow models, shockwave analysis, signal warrant analysis, and safety analysis.  Course includes applications of modeling and simulation to isolated intersections.

courseDescription: Individual analytical, experimental and/or design study selected by the student.  Approved and supervised by the advisor.
Individual project, investigation under the direction of the student’s major professor.
Research leading to the Master of Science thesis.

courseTitle: Civil and Environmental Engineering Experimental Design
courseDescription: Graduate-level overview of engineering experimental design and analysis with emphasis on statistical methods; practical and proper statistical methods applicable to multidisciplinary, real-world civil and environmental engineering problems.

courseTitle: Applied Mathematics for Civil and Environmental Engineers
courseDescription: An examination of numerical and approximate mathematical methods for civil and environmental engineers with applications; finite-difference and finite-integral techniques for single and simultaneous ordinary differential equations; classical and finite-difference solutions of partial differential equations such as heat, wave, Laplace, and plate equation; and finite element applications selected from geotechnical, environmental, hydraulics/water resources, ocean, transportation, and structural engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Classical solutions of partial differential equations
Finite-difference solutions of partial differential equations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of mathematical methods in engineering problems
Analyzing and solving simultaneous ordinary differential equations

courseDescription: Free and forced vibration of discrete and continuous systems; elastic and inelastic response of structures under dynamic loads.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of free and forced vibration of structures
Understanding discrete and continuous systems dynamics
Elastic and inelastic response analysis under dynamic loads
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in analyzing dynamic structural behavior
Analytical skills in structural response evaluation

courseDescription: To provide an understanding of the finite element method (FEM) as derived from an integral formulation perspective.  To demonstrate the solutions of (1-D and 2-D) continuum mechanics problems such as solid mechanics, fluid mechanics and heat transfer.
Ultimate-strength theory, yield line methods, limit design, and other relevant advanced topics in the theory and design of concrete structures.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of concrete design options
Innovative solutions for complex concrete structures

courseDescription: Analysis and design of prestressed concrete members and structures.  Shrinkage, creep and losses, shear, bond and anchorages are discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of shrinkage, creep, and losses in prestressed concrete
Knowledge of shear in prestressed concrete
Understanding of bond and anchorages in prestressed concrete
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of prestressed concrete properties

courseDescription: Elastic analysis of framed structures using matrix and numerical techniques.

Formulation and solution algorithms for Linear Programming (LP) problems.  Unconstrained and constrained nonlinear programming (NLP) problems. Optimum solution for practical engineering systems.  (Cross-listed with MAE 715 and MAE 815)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Algorithmic solutions for LP and NLP

courseDescription: Design of steel, concrete, and composite bridges using modern techniques and current specifications.

Analysis and design of flood protective shields for residential and commercial buildings, floodwalls and gates under hydrostatic, hydrodynamic, and floating debris impact forces, safety of dams and levees, sea-level rise issues for buildings and bridges, ASCE, IBC, and FEMA guidelines for flood resistant structural design, case histories.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of ASCE, IBC, and FEMA guidelines
Safety assessment of dams and levees
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with engineers and architects on flood-resistant solutions
Presentation of case histories and findings to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of floating debris impact forces
Identification of vulnerabilities in existing structures
Application of guidelines to real-world scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for flood-resistant design projects

courseDescription: Inelastic analysis and behavior of framed structures.
Fundamentals of elastic and inelastic stability of beams, columns and frames.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding elastic and inelastic behavior of structures
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of failure modes in beams, columns, and frames
Application of stability criteria in structural design

courseDescription: Classical and modern methods for the solution of plates of various shapes and boundary conditions, continuous and axially loaded plates and plates on elastic supports.  Design examples.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of plates of various shapes and boundary conditions
Continuous and axially loaded plates analysis
Analysis of plates on elastic supports

courseDescription: Detailed numerical step-by-step procedures to exploit parallel and sparse computation under MPI (Message, Passing, Interface) computer environments are explained.  Large-scale engineering/science applications are emphasized.  Simultaneous linear equations are discussed.
Analysis and design of steel structures under seismic loading conditions, introduction to design specifications for steel structures.

courseTitle: Retrofitting Methods for Bridges and Buildings
courseDescription: Retrofitting methods for bridges and buildings combined with related advanced structural analysis and design techniques.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team collaboration in retrofitting projects
Clear communication of structural analysis results
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing retrofitting solutions based on analysis

courseDescription: This course covers structural systems integrated with sensing, data processing, and control devices, which control and reduce the vibration of structures. Students will learn about basic theories of smart structures, smart materials, sensors, structural health monitoring (SHM) as well as their application to civil infrastructures.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for smart structure initiatives

courseDescription: Advanced analysis and design of shallow and deep foundations and retaining structures.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with construction teams for foundation implementation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of soil properties for foundation design
Optimization of foundation design based on site conditions

courseDescription: Detailed study of shear strength of soils and its application to slope stability and embankment design and analysis.  Advanced laboratory shear tests are included.

courseDescription: Detailed study of physiochemical behavior of soils, fabric, rheology, effective stress path, and their applications to various geotechnical engineering problems.
Study of soil behavior under dynamic loadings.  Laboratory and field techniques for determining soil properties and liquefaction potential.  Design examples.

Effective communication of soil properties findings to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of soil behavior data

Problem-solving in design examples based on soil characteristics

courseDescription: Momentum and energy principles, design of open channels, use of mathematical models for flow calculations in rivers, introduction to unsteady open channel flow.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of momentum and energy principles in open channels
Mathematical modeling for flow calculations in rivers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in unsteady open channel flow scenarios

courseDescription: Mathematical formulations of laws governing groundwater flow and contaminant transport. Unsaturated flow.  Use of computer models for modeling groundwater aquifers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing computer models for aquifer simulation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of groundwater flow laws

courseDescription: Physical and chemical processes used in the treatment of water and waste water are covered.  Separation, isolation and reaction processes are characterized as well as reactor engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physical and chemical processes in water treatment
Knowledge of separation and isolation processes

courseDescription: The use of microorganisms to treat domestic and industrial waste waters for organics and nutrient removal are studied.  Characteristics of individual waste water components and the appropriate treatment processes to remove these components are covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of microorganisms in wastewater treatment
Knowledge of treatment processes for organics and nutrient removal
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing characteristics of waste water components

courseTitle: Advanced Processes for Water and Wastewater Treatment
courseDescription: Theory, operation and application of advanced water and waste water treatment systems, including land application, dissolved solids, organic contaminant and nutrient removal processes.  Emphasis on system development for waste water reclamation/recycling.
Technical and Digital Skills: Operation of advanced water treatment systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for assessing treatment efficiency

courseDescription: A lecture and laboratory course dealing with the study of the principles and applications of microbiology in waste water treatment, water treatment, stream self-purification and their effects in environmental engineering.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on experiments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing microbial impacts on environmental engineering processes
Troubleshooting microbiology-related issues in treatment systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating group projects in the course

courseDescription: Characterization of water quality in natural systems and the human activities that result in contaminant input to these systems are studied. Management practices for minimizing contaminant input and for restoring contaminated waters are discussed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Public speaking on water quality issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation for water quality assessment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for water quality improvement initiatives
Team coordination in water restoration projects

courseDescription: Formulation of mathematical equations to describe the fate and transport of aqueous contaminants in dynamic surface water systems.  Use of water quality computer models to predict various contamination scenarios.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of water quality data

courseDescription: The course presents an overview of carbon-free energy sources (nuclear, wind, solar, hydropower, and geothermal). The current status, conversion processes, economics, and environmental issues of these forms of energy will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of wind, solar, hydropower, and geothermal technologies
Economic evaluation of carbon-free energy sources

Collaboration with diverse stakeholders in clean energy projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of energy data for decision-making
Evaluation of energy efficiency and sustainability metrics
Identification and resolution of environmental issues related to clean energy sources
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in carbon-free energy initiatives
Leadership in sustainable energy development projects

courseDescription: This course is focused on the importance of management of phosphorous in preserving sustainable environments. The objectives of the course are to provide an overview of different phosphorous management/recovering/recycling strategies; basics of circular economy; role of microalgae in recovery and recycling of phosphorous; phosphorous recovery from wastewater; and application of the principles of circular economy towards global and regional phosphorous management.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of circular economy concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of circular economy applications in phosphorous management
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in phosphorous recovery initiatives
Leading circular economy practices for phosphorous management

courseTitle: Water Resources Processes and Analysis Methods
courseDescription: This course examines interactive hydrologic processes in water resource; modifications of climate change to these processes; and modern simulation and systematic analysis methods incorporating the modifications into practices of water resource planning, utilization, protection, and engineering.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Incorporating climate change factors into analysis

courseDescription: Chemical reactions in natural and engineered systems are studied with emphasis placed on developing kinetic expressions and assessing chemical equilibrium.  Kinetic and equilibrium expressions are applied to engineering problems to predict the reaction time and products of specific reactions.

This course focuses on major transportation safety issues including transportation safety goals, safety of various transportation modes, identification of problematic locations, selection of safety countermeasures and their evaluation, safety data and modeling issues.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with transportation stakeholders for safety improvements

courseDescription: This is the second course in transportation operations and traffic flow theory.  Topics covered include design of progressive signal systems, queuing theory, car following models, and applications of microscopic traffic simulation to corridor studies.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying queuing theory to traffic scenarios
Utilizing car following models for traffic optimization

courseDescription: This course examines how ITS can be used to enhance mobility and safety. The topics covered in the course include systems engineering approach to ITS, traveler response to technologies and information, ITS planning and evaluation, and ITS deployment and operational performance.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with stakeholders in ITS projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing traveler response to technologies and information in ITS

courseDescription: This course covers transportation planning processes that include policy direction, transportation data, travel demand forecasting models, and decision-making/stakeholders issues.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of transportation plans and data
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying transportation issues and proposing solutions

courseDescription: This course provides a rigorous introduction to transportation network modeling, with special emphasis on network equilibrium problems. Topics include: elementary graph theory, shortest path problem nonlinear optimization, optimization of univariate functions, deterministic and stochastic user equilibrium.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Deterministic and stochastic user equilibrium analysis

courseDescription: Fundamental models and algorithms in optimization, stochastic modeling and parallel computing will be discussed and illustrated with transportation applications.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Optimal route planning in transportation networks

courseDescription: Principles of simulation modeling. Microscopic, mesoscopic and macroscopic traffic simulation models. Driver behavior in networks. Calibration and validation of traffic simulation models. Traffic simulation software.
Technical and Digital Skills: Calibration and validation of simulation models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding microscopic, mesoscopic, and macroscopic traffic simulation models

courseDescription: The class focuses on the development of econometric modeling and its application in the field of transportation engineering. Topics to be covered include statistical inference, linear regression, count data models, discrete choice models, survival analysis, time series modeling, spatial modeling, panel data analysis, and structural equation modeling. Students will have a better understanding of the concepts and theories of econometrics and will be equipped with well-suited modeling and analysis techniques.

Nonlinear wave theories; wave forces on slender piles and seawalls; design of rubblemound structures; design philosophy, initial costs, maintenance costs, optimized design using stochastic methods; design of renourished beaches.  Advanced alternative solutions for shore protection.
Technical and Digital Skills: Wave forces on slender piles and seawalls
Advanced alternative solutions for shore protection
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing wave forces on coastal structures
Applying stochastic methods for design optimization

courseDescription: Types of dredges, factors affecting dredge performance; hydraulic dredges (cutter, hopper) and mechanical dredges systems (bucket, clamshell, etc.); shoaling rate determination; inlet sand bypassing systems; beach renourishment schemes.  Design of beach renourishment/projects.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with team members on dredging projects
Effectively communicating dredging project requirements to stakeholders
Presenting beach renourishment design proposals to clients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying optimal dredging methods for specific scenarios
Solving challenges related to beach renourishment projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a dredging team during project execution
Organizing resources for efficient dredging operations
Managing timelines for beach renourishment projects

courseDescription: This course discusses the hydrodynamics of the coastal environment and reviews waves, low-frequency motions, and coastal responses, including sediment processes and beach evolution. Specific topics to be covered include: review of linear wave theory; introduction to nonlinear waves; wave-averaged motions and radiation stresses; wave and current boundary layers; wave setup, longshore current, rip current, undertow, and nearshore circulation; wave dissipation mechanisms; and fluid-sediment interaction. An introduction to cohesive sediments, sediment concentration and transport models, and beach morphology will also be addressed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Wave-averaged motions and radiation stresses comprehension
Familiarity with wave and current boundary layers
Introduction to sediment concentration and transport models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of sediment processes knowledge in real-world scenarios

courseDescription: Fluid dynamics conservation laws as transport phenomena.  Classical, finite-difference models for advection, diffusion and combined fluid flows.  Explicit and implicit schemes to solve unsteady, free-surface fluid flow and diffusion (dispersion) problems in one and multi-dimensions.  Turbulence models.
Technical and Digital Skills: Explicit and implicit schemes for solving fluid flow problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of advection and diffusion models

courseTitle: Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in civil and/or environmental engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Recent developments in civil and environmental engineering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Innovative problem-solving approaches in civil and environmental contexts

courseTitle: Civil and Environmental Engineering Experimental Design
courseDescription: Graduate-level overview of engineering experimental design and analysis with emphasis on statistical methods; practical and proper statistical methods applicable to multidisciplinary, real-world civil and environmental engineering problems.

courseTitle: Applied Mathematics for Civil and Environmental Engineers
courseDescription: An examination of numerical and approximate mathematical methods for civil and environmental engineers with applications; finite-difference and finite-integral techniques for single and simultaneous ordinary differential equations; classical and finite-difference solutions of partial differential equations such as heat, wave, Laplace, and plate equation; and finite element applications selected from geotechnical, environmental, hydraulics/water resources, ocean, transportation, and structural engineering.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in civil and environmental engineering contexts

courseDescription: Free and forced vibration of discrete and continuous systems; elastic and inelastic response of structures under dynamic loads.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in dynamic systems analysis

courseDescription: To provide an understanding of the finite element method (FEM) as derived from an integral formulation perspective.  To demonstrate the solutions of (1-D and 2-D) continuum mechanics problems such as solid mechanics, fluid mechanics and heat transfer.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integration of FEM in mechanics problems

courseDescription: Ultimate-strength theory, yield line methods, limit design, and other relevant advanced topics in the theory and design of concrete structures.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical approach to complex concrete scenarios

courseDescription: Analysis and design of prestressed concrete members and structures.  Shrinkage, creep and losses, shear, bond and anchorages are discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis and design of prestressed concrete members
Understanding of shrinkage, creep, and losses in prestressed concrete
Knowledge of shear forces in prestressed concrete
Understanding bond and anchorages in prestressed concrete
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of prestressed concrete design

courseDescription: Elastic analysis of framed structures using matrix and numerical techniques.

Formulation and solution algorithms for Linear Programming (LP) problems.  Unconstrained and constrained nonlinear programming (NLP) problems. Optimum solution for practical engineering systems.  (Cross-listed with MAE 715/MAE 815)
Technical and Digital Skills: Optimum solution for practical engineering systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Algorithm design for LP and NLP problems

courseDescription: Design of steel, concrete, and composite bridges using modern techniques and current specifications.

Analysis and design of flood protective shields for residential and commercial buildings, floodwalls and gates under hydrostatic, hydrodynamic, and floating debris impact forces, safety of dams and levees, sea-level rise issues for buildings and bridges, ASCE, IBC, and FEMA guidelines for flood resistant structural design, case histories.

Safety assessment of dams and levees
Understanding ASCE, IBC, and FEMA guidelines for flood resistant structural design

courseDescription: Inelastic analysis and behavior of framed structures.

courseDescription: Classical and modern methods for the solution of plates of various shapes and boundary conditions, continuous and axially loaded plates and plates on elastic supports.  Design examples.

courseDescription: Detailed numerical step-by-step procedures to exploit parallel and sparse computation under MPI (Message, Passing, Interface) computer environments are explained.  Large-scale engineering/science applications are emphasized.  Simultaneous linear equations are discussed.
Analysis and design of steel structures under seismic loading conditions, introduction to design specifications for steel structures.

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation. courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
